H0.text: Transport of material inside the cell is the cell function most directly dependent on the cytoskeleton.

H1.text: The response of the cell to external pathogens is the cell function most directly dependent on the cytoskeleton.

H2.text: Storage of energy in stable long-term forms is the cell function most directly dependent on the cytoskeleton.

H3.text: Direction of cellular activity is the cell function most directly dependent on the cytoskeleton.

A4.text: Since intracellular transport heavily relies on microtubules for movement, the components of the cytoskeleton play a vital role in trafficking vesicles between organelles and the plasma membrane by providing mechanical support.

A5.text: Microtubules are organized so their plus ends extend through the periphery of the cells and their minus ends are anchored within the centrosome, so they utilize the motor proteins kinesin's (positive end directed) and dynein's (negative end directed) to transport vesicles and organelles in opposite directions through the cytoplasm.

A6.text: The anisotropy of the cytoskeleton serves to more keenly direct cell responses to intra or extracellular signals.

A7.text: It is involved in the uptake of extracellular material (endocytosis).

A8.text: Animation of leukocyte adhesion (Animation with some images of actin and microtubule assembly and dynamics.)

A9.text: It can be concluded that microtubules act both to restrain cell movement and to establish directionality.

A10.text: Microtubules can act as substrates for motor proteins that are involved in important cellular functions such as vesicle trafficking and cell division.

A11.text: Myosin motors are intracellular ATP-dependent enzymes that bind to and move along actin filaments.

A12.text: The Arp2/3 complex nucleates the formation of a new daughter filament at a 70-degree angle relative to the mother filament, effecting a fan‑like branched filament network.

A13.text: Dynein deficiencies can lead to chronic infections of the respiratory tract as cilia fail to function without dynein.

A14.text: Non‑muscle myosin II bipolar thick filaments provide the force of contraction needed to divide the cell into two daughter cells during cytokinesis.

A15.text: High drug concentrations, or microtubule mutations that depolymerize the microtubules, can restore cell migration but there is a loss of directionality.

A16.text: Leading edge at the front of a migrating cell is also the site at which membrane from internal membrane pools is returned to the cell surface at the end of the endocytic cycle.

A17.text: The process of cell uptake depends on the tilt and chirality of constituent molecules to induce membrane budding.

A18.text: Caveolin proteins bind to the inner leaflet via cholesterol, the membrane starts to bend, leading to spontaneous curvature.

A19.text: Vesicles that transport proteins from the Golgi apparatus to the cell surface area, will be likely to use motor proteins and a cytoskeletal track to get closer to their target.

A20.text: Non‑constitutive exocytosis and subsequent endocytosis are highly energy expending processes, and thus, are dependent on mitochondria.

A21.text: It can spur the rearrangement of the cytoskeleton, or even as catalysis by an enzyme.
